Headline: First Bk Of Nigeria Plans Debut Tier 2 Dollar Bond - Source
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--First Bank of Nigeria is planning its debut dollar-denominated subordinated bond, said a person familiar with the deal Friday.   The bonds should have a 10-year structure, callable in five years, and the mandate announcement is likely to come out sometime next week, depending on market conditions, the person added.   Standard & Poor's Corp. rates First Bank Of Nigeria BB-. The rating reflects the bank's strong market position as one of Nigeria's leading financial service providers; its robust funding and liquidity profile; sound risk governance; and the benefits starting to derive from its expansion into the fast developing retail banking market, said Standard & Poor's credit analysts in a ratings note.   The ratings are constrained by the high economic and industry risks associated with operating in Nigeria, which is also rated BB-, the banks barely adequate capitalization, high operating costs, and increasing competition, the analysts added.   -By Peppi Kiviniemi, Dow Jones Newswires, 44 20 7842 9496; peppi.kiviniemi@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 02, 2007 05:29 ET (10:29 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJE(3/2) New Business Lifts Royal Bank Of Scotland Net 15%
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL EUROPE)     By Simon Kennedy and Henry Teitelbaum   LONDON -- Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC said its full-year net profit rose 15% as it won more customers and increased lending.   The bank said net profit rose to GBP 6.2 billion ($12.2 billion) in 2006 from GBP 5.39 billion in 2005. Total income rose 9.5% to GBP 28 billion from GBP 25.57 billion.   The bank's cost-to-income ratio fell to 42.1% from 42.4%, though net interest margin also slipped, to 2.47% from 2.55%. Impairment losses rose to GBP 1.88 billion from GBP 1.71 billion but were stable at 0.46% of loans and advances.   Royal Bank of Scotland said it plans to raise its dividend for the year by 25% to 90.60 pence a share after consultation with shareholders showed a preference for dividends.   The bank said its global banking and markets division saw the strongest growth, with operating profit rising 25% to GBP 3.79 billion following further investment in the unit's geographical reach and product range. The division's growth also reflects the bank's growing strength in global debt capital markets and stronger results from its origination and structuring business, RBS said.   Alex Potter, an analyst at Collins Stewart in London, said the division's profit was about GBP 200 million ahead of expectations, adding the quality of the result was also strong, as it was due to fees rather than volatile trading profits.   The retail-markets division's operating profit rose 5% to GBP 2.65 billion as the bank sharpened its focus on savings and investing and further reduced its exposure in the direct loans market. The move away from loans meant arrears in the second half of the year were flat compared to the first half, though total bad-debt charges for the year rose 10% from 2005 to GBP 1.88 billion.   In its U.S. Citizens division, RBS said operating profit rose 2% to $2.92 billion.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 02, 2007 00:32 ET (05:32 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: ASIA G3 BOND OUTLOOK: Pusan Goes Ahead But Others Cautious
Story: By Ditas Lopez     Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     SINGAPORE (Dow Jones)--The plunge in global equity and bond prices earlier this week is sending some would-be Asian borrowers back to the drawing board to reassess their fund-raising plans, which looks set to slow the primary deal flow in the coming weeks.   But not everyone is deterred. Pusan Bank, for one, is pushing ahead with its plan to sell its debut international bond next week.   The South Korean bank will kick off roadshows for a US$200 million Lower Tier 2 bond in Singapore on Monday, proceed to Hong Kong on Tuesday and wrap up marketing in London Wednesday. The bank still aims to price the debt following the roadshows, according to a person familiar with the deal.   The bank has tapped JPMorgan Chase & Co. and UBS AG to help sell its subordinated note, which is due 2017 and callable in five years.   Pusan Bank is the dominant bank in Busan, South Korea's second-largest city. The bank had total assets of KRW22.8 trillion (US$24.2 billion) at the end of 2006 and total capital adequacy ratio of 11.09%, of which 3% was Tier 2.   Earlier this year, the bank said it expects its CAR to rise to 11.41% by the end of this year and its net profit to increase 28% from KRW184 billion last year.   Moody's Investors Service rates the proposed issue at Baa3 while Fitch Ratings has assigned it a ranking of BBB.   No South Korean bank has sold a subordinated bond this year meaning there are no direct comparables in Pusan's home country. Last year, Shinhan Bank, rated one notch higher than Pusan, sold a subordinated bond callable in 2011. That was last quoted at a spread of around 108 basis points over U.S. Treasurys.   Details of the roadshows for Pusan Bank's bond offering emerged even as Asian U.S. dollar bonds were suffering from a global market fallout.   The latest jitters, sparked by worries the government in Beijing would make further efforts to slow the booming Chinese economy, came after a sustained rally in Asian bonds in the last few years.   But since the market rout on Wednesday, bids have started to creep back into Asia's bond markets.   "Market volatility is nothing new, we just haven't seen it for a while. Issuers who are prepared to approach the market with realistic pricing targets can get deals done. Investors remain in buy mode," said Mark Leahy, head of Asian syndicate at Deutsche Bank AG.       KDB Assessing Market Conditions     Others, though, are taking a more cautious view than Pusan Bank.   Korean Development Bank, which just last week said it could announce mandates for an offshore bond in the week starting Mar. 12, said it continues to watch market conditions.   "I can say nothing is fixed yet," said Injoo Kim, head of funding at the Seoul-based bank. "As you know, the market is not in a good condition. The bank is assessing the market and doing the internal process of finding out its funding requirement," he said.   KDB is looking to raise the equivalent of at least US$500 million from the offshore market within the first quarter.   Other names keen to tap the offshore debt market in March also include South Korea's largest chemical manufacturer LG Chem Ltd.   LG Chem is looking to raise US$100 million through a dual-tranche loan-style floating-rate note, according to a person familiar with the deal. The deal is equally split between maturities of 2.5- and 3.5 years, the person said.   The proceeds from the sale, expected to take place around mid-March, will be used to refinance existing debt.   ING, in charge of the fund-raising, has invited a few other banks to help arrange the transaction and will announce their names in the coming week.   While bankers don't doubt that the region's borrowers can raise funds in the international bond market, some question whether coming to the market at this time will yield optimum results for either borrowers or investors.   Sun Hung Kai Properties Ltd., Hong Kong's largest property developer in terms of market capitalization, late Thursday sold a US$300 million 10-year bond at 83 basis points over U.S. Treasurys - in line with the announced guidance.   Some market participants, however, said Sun Hung Kai Properties could have priced the bond at a spread around 10 basis points tighter had it sold the paper last week.   There are no official data on subscriptions for the offering but people not involved in the transaction said there was talk that the order book stood at around US$350 million just hours before the pricing.   "I don't think it's a question of whether borrowers can borrow because they definitely can. It's a question of how much they have to pay for that in the current market. That's a multi-million dollar question," said a syndicate banker in Hong Kong.   "Our sense from the accounts is that they understand there are volatilities there. They are not really spooked by the market but at the same time, they really want to make sure that the spread for the risk they are taking is fair," the banker added.     -By Ditas Lopez, Dow Jones Newswires; +65-6415-4044; ditas.lopez@dowjones.com   -Edited by Karen Lane     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 02, 2007 03:18 ET (08:18 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Adecco 06 Net Pft Jumps 35%, Mid-Term Targets Intact
Story: By Goran Mijuk   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     ZURICH (Dow Jones)--Adecco SA (ADO) Friday reported a 35% rise in full-year net profit thanks to a strong performance in the U.S. and France, and said it was on track to reach its medium-term targets.   The world's largest temporary employment company in terms of sales - ahead of Manpower Inc (MAN) - said 2006 net profit rose to EUR611 million from EUR453 million a year ago.   The figure beat analyst calls for a bottom line result of EUR540 million, as the company also profited from tax benefits and a generally lower tax rate.   For the fourth quarter, net profit jumped 23% to EUR212 million from EUR171 million, also beating forecasts.   "Our value-oriented management approach and focus on professional and specialized staffing, combined with the continued favorable economic environment for the industry as a whole, make me optimistic about Adecco's future growth and returns", said Chief Executive Dieter Scheiff.   "We are well on track to reach our long-term goals of 7% to 9% annual revenue growth, as well as an operating margin of over 5% and a return on capital employed of above  25% by 2009," he said.   In 2006, full-year sales rose 12% to EUR20.42 billion from EUR18.30 billion a year-ago, while the operation margin improved to 4% from an earlier 3.4%. Return on capital employed reached 20.3% in 2006, up from 18.5% in 2005.   The strong result was mainly spurred by a turnaround in France and the U.S., the company's two key markets.   Adecco was able to boost full-year sales in France by 8% to EUR6.8 billion and improve its gross margin by 10 basis points.   In the U.S., sales rose 1% to EUR3.7 billion while the gross margin improved by 110 basis points.   Adecco also said the it will propose a dividend of CHF1.20 per share for 2006, up from CHF 1.00 in 2005.     Company Web Site: http://www.adecco.com     -By Goran Mijuk, Dow Jones Newswires; +41 43 443 80 47; goran.mijuk@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 02, 2007 01:26 ET (06:26 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJE(3/2) WEEKEND JOURNAL: Collecting: Film Classics You Can Wear Costumes Worn By James Bond, Mel Gibson, Madonna In London Auction
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL EUROPE)   ANYONE WHO'S ever dreamed of wearing a seductive James Bond dinner jacket or Madonna dress to a fancy party will get the chance Tuesday, when Bonham's London auctions Angels The Costumiers' extensive collection of film costumes.   Now in its 167th year, Angels of London is the world's longest-established supplier of costumes to the film, theater and television industries. The more than 400 Angels outfits in this sale will be the largest such collection to ever come on the European auction market.   While certain iconic film outfits -- Audrey Hepburn's dress from "Breakfast at Tiffany's" or Judy Garland's outfit from "The Wizard of Oz" -- have fetched astronomical prices, many pieces of film history are relative bargains. Some can be had for as little as GBP 100.   Among the stars represented in the Angels sale -- by their costumes, at least -- will be Sean Connery, Pierce Brosnan, Richard Burton, Robert De Niro, Alain Delon, Errol Flynn, Ava Gardner, Mel Gibson, Alec Guinness, Peter Ustinov, Catherine Zeta Jones, Halle Berry, Andie MacDowell, Madonna, Kevin Costner, Meryl Streep and Harrison Ford.   The outfits were featured in such films as "Cleopatra" (1963), "Thunderball" (1965), "Star Wars" (1977), "Death on the Nile" (1978), "Out of Africa" (1985), "Robin Hood: Prince of Thieves" (1991), "Four Weddings and a Funeral" (1994), "Braveheart" (1995), "Goldeneye" (1996), "Evita" (1996) and "Tomorrow Never Dies" (1997).   Angels supplied its first Academy Award-winning costumes for Laurence Olivier's version of "Henry V" in 1946; up until this year, it had worked on another 26 Oscar-winning films. Among this year's crop of Oscar nominees, Angels supplied costuming for "The Queen" and for "Marie Antoinette" (which won in the Best Achievement in Costume Design category). Angels makes its costumes for hire and then rents them to the filmmakers. After shooting is completed they are returned to the firm, which retains ownership.   "It hurts a bit to part with iconic costumes that have helped to make cinema history," says chairman Tim Angel, whose family has run the firm for five generations. But, he adds, it made business sense to sell pieces that were costing too much in insurance premiums.   Despite such everyday pressures, Mr. Angel says he loves the costume business. "I loved history at school and I was lucky enough to be in a family business that allowed me to live history," he says.   A growing number of collectors and fans who want to own a piece of film history are driving the costume market, says Bonhams specialist Adrian Cowdry. "Movies are the art form of the 20th century," says Mr. Cowdry, who privately collects items related to James Bond. If he had his pick of the Angels auction, Mr. Cowdry said he would love to buy -- "if only I could afford it" -- Sean Connery's dinner jacket of black wool, with satin collar, cuffs and buttons from the film "Thunderball" (estimate: GBP 30,000-GBP 40,000).   The costumes of film icons can fetch very high prices. In 1999, Christie's New York sold for $1.27 million the dress worn by Marilyn Monroe in 1962 when she sang "Happy Birthday" to President John F. Kennedy at Madison Square Garden. In 2005, Bonhams sold the gingham dress worn by Ms. Garland in "The Wizard of Oz" (1939) for GBP 140,000. At Christie's in London last December, the iconic black dress designed by Hubert de Givenchy for Ms. Hepburn in "Breakfast at Tiffany's" (1961) fetched GBP 467,200. However, such prices are the peak of the market. Most pieces are significantly lower.   Here are some of the diverse costumes featured in the Angels sale, where estimates range from GBP 100 to GBP 60,000.   A number of pieces worn by Pierce Brosnan as James Bond are included. From "Goldeneye" comes a three-piece, grey wool suit designed by Brioni with shirt and tie (estimate: GBP 8,000-GBP 10,000); a cream linen Brioni suit with a Turnbull & Asser sea-island blue cotton shirt from the same film (GBP 8,000-GBP 10,000); and a green quilted ski suit from "The World is Not Enough" from 1997 (estimate: GBP 6,000-GBP 8,000).   Also among the costumes from the Bond films is a pair of camouflage combat trousers worn by Halle Berry in "Die Another Day" (2002) estimated at GBP 800-GBP 1,000.   From "Star Wars" comes an imperial commander's uniform estimated at GBP 8,000-GBP 10,000. "Star Wars" also provides the top lot of the sale in the full-length brown cloak with hood worn by Alec Guinness as Obi Wan Kenobi in the first film of the series (GBP 50,000-GBP 60,000).   Andie MacDowell was a hit in "Four Weddings and a Funeral." From that film comes her wide-brimmed black hat of woven straw with large black taffeta bow estimated at a very modest GBP 150-GBP 200. Also estimated at that price is Ms. MacDowell's chiffon blouse, beaded bra and satin trousers from the same film.   Jewelry highlights include a number of artificial and paste items worn by Ms. Zeta Jones in the 1990 film "1001 Nights" (also known in the U.K. as "Scheherazade") estimated together at GBP 300-GBP 400; and an artificial jewelled crucifix and ring worn by Mr. De Niro in the 1986 film "The Mission" (estimate: GBP 150-GBP 200).   The elaborate robe worn by Richard Burton as Henry VIII in "Anne of a Thousand Days" (1969), the tale of the king's relationship with his ill-fated Queen Anne Boleyn, is estimated at GBP 500-GBP 700. Sean Connery's outfit as Richard the Lion Heart in "Robin Hood: Prince of Thieves" (1991) is expected to fetch GBP 4,000-GBP 5,000 -- as is the costume worn by Mel Gibson as William Wallace in the Scottish saga "Braveheart" (1995).   ---   Angels Star Collection of Film   & TV Costumes.   Bonhams, Montpelier Street, Knightsbridge, London   March 6, 11 a.m. and 2 p.m.   Presale viewings: March 3 and 4,   11 a.m.-3 p.m.; March 5, 9 a.m.-7 p.m.   44-20-7447-7447   www.bonhams.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 02, 2007 00:30 ET (05:30 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Citizens Holding Company Announces Cash Dividend of $.18 Per Share
Story: PHILADELPHIA, Miss.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--March 02, 2007--   Citizens Holding Company (NASDAQ: CIZN) announced today that its Board of Directors declared a cash dividend of $0.18 per share payable March 30, to shareholders of record as of March 15, 2007.     "The first quarter 2007 dividend that we are announcing today of $0.18 per share is an increase of 5.9% over the $0.17 per share paid in the first quarter of 2006," said Greg L. McKee, President and Chief Executive Officer.     Citizens Holding Company is a one-bank holding company and the parent company of The Citizens Bank of Philadelphia, both headquartered in Philadelphia, Mississippi. The Bank has nineteen full service banking locations in eight counties in East Central Mississippi. In addition to full service commercial banking, the Company offers mortgage loans, title insurance services through its subsidiary, Title Services, LLC and a full range of Internet banking services including online banking, bill pay and cash management services for businesses. Internet services are available at the Bank web site, www.thecitizensbankphila.com. Citizens Holding Company stock is listed on the NASDAQ Global Market and is traded under the symbol CIZN. The Company's transfer agent is American Stock Transfer & Trust Company. Investor relations information may be obtained at the corporate website, www.citizensholdingcompany.com. Smith, 601/656-4692               rsmith@netdoor.com        SOURCE: Citizens Holding Company  Copyright Business Wire 2007     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 02, 2007 08:00 ET (13:00 GMT)

Headline: : Napier Environmental Technologies Inc.: Shares Issued Upon Exercise Of Warrants>NIR.T
Story: VANCOUVER, BRITISH COLUMBIA--(CCNMatthews - March 1, 2007) - Napier Environmental Technologies Inc. (TSX:NIR) reports that it has issued 41,076,850 common shares to 6408753 Canada Corporation upon exercise of previously issued warrants. These warrants were issued to one of the lenders to Napier upon entering into a Credit Agreement to provide $2,500,000 of debt financing in July 2005. Napier has no more unexercised warrants. Subsequent to these shares being issued, there are a total of 129,921,742 common shares issued and outstanding, approximately 31.6% of which are held by 6408753 Canada Corporation. The exercise of these warrants results in proceeds to Napier of $410,769. Napier will use the proceeds to partially repay its lenders, 6408788 Canada Corp. and 6408753 Canada Corporation.    About Napier    Napier is a Canadian company primarily engaged in the development, manufacture and distribution of a wide range of products utilizing environmentally advanced technology. The product lines include coating removal and wood restoration products for both the industrial/commercial market and the consumer/retail market. Napier is in the process of extending its product line by utilizing environmentally sound technology in the lawn and garden and household cleaning industries.    This release and referenced materials contain forward-looking statements that are subject to a number of known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other factors that may cause actual results to differ materially from those anticipated in Napier's forward-looking statements. Such factors include, among others, risks related to the completion of the acquisitions of PN and PN US, risks related to going concern status of Napier, historical losses and cash flow, the future need for capital and uncertainty of additional financing being available, the potential dilution to shareholders, the volatility of the market price of the common shares, the historical lack of dividend payments, competition, dependence on key personnel, dependence on key customers, weather, seasonality and economic cycles, the availability of raw materials, the retail industry and the influence of economic conditions and consumer behavior, exchange rate fluctuations and conflicts of interest. For further details regarding such risk factors, see the section entitled "Description of the Business - Risk Factors" in Napier's annual information form dated March 30, 2006 and filed with the British Columbia and Ontario securities commissions and the Toronto Stock Exchange, which can be found on SEDAR at www.sedar.com. Although Napier has attempted to identify important factors that could cause actual actions, events or results not to be as anticipated, estimated or intended. Accordingly, readers should not place undue reliance on forward-looking statements. Headline: INSINGER DE BEAUFORT: German Data Douse Growth Hopes
Story: By Stephen Lewis     Of Insinger de Beaufort     LONDON (Dow Jones)--The German retail sales data for January, published earlier today, came as a reality check to financial markets grown complacent about euro zone growth prospects.   In the early days of 2007, the markets and some policymakers managed to convince themselves that the German value-added tax hike on 1 January was having scarcely any impact on consumer demand. This belief was parallel to the illusion in the U.S. that the economy there was holding up well, despite the malaise in the housing sector.   These responses were understandable reactions against previous undue pessimism. Indeed, the U.S. housing downturn is still far from triggering recession but it hasn't left the U.S. economy unscathed. The truth of the situation lies between those extremes. Similarly in Europe, the VAT hike has not cut short the economic upswing but it is unrealistic to suppose it is having only negligible impact on German consumer spending. If it were, it would be the first example in history of a major hike in indirect taxes having no effect on the timing of consumer spending flows.   The view that German consumers were taking the VAT rate increase in their stride was based largely on rather subdued consumer spending data for 2006Q4. It was widely assumed these figures showed there had been very little preemptive spending ahead of the tax hike. It seemed to follow there would be hardly a ripple in spending after the tax rate was raised.   This analysis left out of account the fact that some areas of consumer spending were certainly displaying unusual strength in the fourth quarter of last year. New registrations of passenger cars, for example, were 11% higher than in 2005Q4, with a year-on-year increase in December alone of 17%. Also, the argument was logically flawed.   Consumer spending could have been subdued in 2006Q4 despite preemptive buying; this would have been the case if underlying expenditure had been very weak. This, in fact, is now the most likely hypothesis. The Bundesbank's estimate of a 9.7% monthly slide in overall retail sales in January suggests that underlying consumer demand is appreciably lower than most forecasters have believed. If this is so, the growth outlook in Germany and, by extension, in the euro zone is less bright than the markets have assumed. As we warned a week ago (see No 2686), the upward trend in revisions to German and euro zone growth forecasts is over. Current GDP projections for 2007 are probably now too high.   To be sure, the German retail sales data are notoriously unreliable as a guide to aggregate consumer spending. Even so, the fall in retail sales recorded for January is so steep that it is hardly plausible to explain it away entirely as the product of shortcomings in the statistics. There is no arguing with the reported 11% year-on-year slump in new car registrations in January, which, incidentally, was followed by a 15% collapse in February.   These numbers are likely to increase the political pressure on the ECB to refrain from further tightening of monetary policy. However, Mr Trichet and his colleagues have consistently maintained they would look through any weakness in demand associated with the German VAT hike. They would, instead, rely on broader trends in the euro zone economy for a policy lead. They are likely to argue that, though the markets and politicians may be dismayed at the latest figures, nothing has happened so far that is out of line with the central bank's expectations.   The ECB is unlikely to see weaker German consumption data as an obstacle to the further withdrawal of monetary accommodation. Its focus will remain on medium-term inflation risks.   At the Ecofin meeting this week, some ministers were saying they saw no signs of inflation picking up in the euro zone economy. Clearly, they aren't devotees of the business surveys. The February purchasing managers' report for the euro zone included an index number for manufacturers' output prices which, since the series began in 2002, had only been topped by January's reading.   They must also be closing their ears to the pay claims that trade unions are lodging in Germany and elsewhere in the euro zone.   The belief that there are no significant inflation pressures may well rest on the recent tendency for CPI inflation to undershoot expectations. The simplistic view is that the ECB must have done enough to achieve its anti-inflation objective. But the pleasant surprises regarding CPI seem chiefly to have reflected the lagged impact of the slide in oil prices, which now seems to have halted if not reversed. The annual increase in the euro zone's CPI (ex energy) measure has pushed up from 1.4% in February last year to 1.9% in January this year.  If unprocessed food is also left out of account (apparently the ECB's favoured core definition), the upswing has been from 1.3% to 1.8%.   A continuation of these trends in core inflation, combined with firm energy prices, would eventually take headline CPI well above 2.0%. In fact, the ECB probably fears something even worse. Should pay settlements start to rise, non-energy prices could accelerate upwards. The ECB would probably argue that its limited success so far in keeping core inflation in check has depended on the general expectation that it will deliver at least two more 25 bps rate increases. If it were to relent in its drive to normalise interest rates, inflation expectations might creep higher.  There are likely to be more disappointments to come on euro zone growth. However, the ECB has envisaged the zone's GDP growing by as little as 1.7% this year.   Though markets will expect the ECB to have second thoughts about tightening further after next week's virtually certain rate hike, the Governing Council consensus is likely to favour a sterner course.     -By Stephen Lewis: (+44) 20 7190 7193; sjlewis@insinger.com   (Stephen Lewis is chief economist at Insinger de Beaufort Ltd., London, independent brokers specializing in institutional business.)   Opinions expressed are those of the author, and not of Dow Jones Newswires.   This column is published for information only, and it neither constitutes, nor is to be construed as, an offer to buy or sell investments. The information and opinions expressed herein are based on sources the author believes to be reliable, but he cannot represent that they are accurate or complete. Any information herein is given in good faith, but is subject to change without notice. No liability is accepted whatsoever by Insinger de Beaufort Ltd., employees and associated companies for any direct or consequential loss arising from this article.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 02, 2007 07:05 ET (12:05 GMT)

Story: MADRID (Dow Jones)--Italian energy company Enel SpA (EN) Friday said it has entered into a share-swap transaction with Italian bank Mediobanca Banca di Credito Finanziario SpA (MB.MI) for an additional 4.5 million shares in Spanish power firm Endesa SA (ELE).   Those shares account for a 0.43% stake in Endesa. Headline: : Tyler Technologies Receives SIF Certification for Its Education Management Solution
Story: DALLAS, March 2 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- Tyler Technologies, Inc. (NYSE: TYL) has been awarded Schools Interoperability Framework (SIF) Certification for the latest release of the Tyler Education Management Solution (TEMS), an advanced Student Information System for the K-12 school market.  This certification acknowledges Tyler's continued dedication to helping schools get the most out of their software investment and follows the certification of Tyler's MUNIS(R) Enterprise Resource Planning system last year.     The SIF Certification Program is an initiative of the Schools Interoperability Framework Association (SIFA), a collaborative association comprised of school districts, states, the U.S. Department of Education, and other pre K-12 organizations.  SIFA promotes standards that allow school districts to easily share information from multiple software systems.  In short, SIF translates data between different systems so that changes to information in one are reflected in all others.     "Our goal is to enhance the teaching and learning environment," said SIFA Project Strategist, Laurie Collins.  "Many schools, districts and states have cited that they not only see a monetary benefit from implementing SIF, but they also gain efficiencies and data quality that is more valuable and harder to quantify."     Currently used in 48 states and four countries, this interoperability has led to measurable cost savings by reducing staff time spent on data entry and re-entry.  It also eliminates the need for cumbersome software customizations that can cost school districts thousands of dollars.     Similar to email applications, SIF makes information available to a number of access points, and encodes data in a way that is vendor neutral and platform independent.  Tying all of this information together is a relatively simple process.  Integration software utility tools act as a liaison between applications and the school district's central server.  However, software companies must align their applications with SIF standards to facilitate the interoperability.  That's exactly what Tyler Technologies has done.     "SIF Certified vendors have gone through rigorous levels of testing," said Collins.  "Schools, districts and states gain assurance that in selecting SIF Certified vendors they have a greater chance of succeeding in gaining the interoperability they desire."     SIF standards also play a critical role in the education reform principles of No Child Left Behind.  The standards help improve accountability and reporting by providing a means to consolidate information effectively.  In doing so, some districts have seen increases in government funding that can be directly attributed to use of SIF Certified applications.     "School districts and states are being held to a higher degree of accountability for the education of our youth," said Collins.  "By using data interoperability standards they can assure the data that they are using to produce the accountability reports are accurate, timely and convey the true status of education."     As the desire for data interoperability continues to grow in education, SIF Certified solutions are becoming more widely sought after.     "School districts often have limited dollars to spend on technology and staffing," said Tyler Technologies President and CEO, John Marr, Jr.  "Using SIF Certified solutions like TEMS and MUNIS(R) allows them put the time and money they save into improving other areas of education."     Based in Dallas, Tyler Technologies is a leading provider of end-to-end information management solutions and services for local governments.  Tyler partners with clients to make local government more accessible to the public, more responsive to needs of citizens, and more efficient.  Tyler's client base includes more than 6,000 local government offices throughout all 50 states, Canada, Puerto Rico and the United Kingdom.  Forbes Magazine named Tyler one of the "200 Best Small Companies" in America in 2004.  More information about Tyler Technologies can be found at http://www.tylertech.com .     Tyler Technologies, Inc. has included in this press release "forward- looking statements" within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 concerning its business and operations.  Tyler Technologies expressly disclaims any obligation to release publicly any updates or revisions to these forward-looking statements to reflect any change in its expectations.  These expectations and the related statements are inherently subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those set forth in, contemplated by, or underlying the forward-looking statements.  The risks and uncertainties which forward-looking statements are subject to include, but are not limited to, changes in competition, changes in general economic conditions, changes in the budgets and regulatory environments of the Company's customers, risks associated with the development of new products and the enhancement of existing products, the ability to attract and retain qualified personnel, and other risks detailed from time to time in the Company's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Headline: : SEBIVO(R) (Telbivudine) Approved in China as New Treatment Option for Patients with Chronic Hepatitis B
Story: -- Chronic hepatitis B affects an estimated 100 million people in China(1) -- SEBIVO(R) recently received positive opinion by the European Medicines Agency, and is already approved and available in the United States under the brand name TYZEKA(R)(telbivudine)       CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 2 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- Idenix Pharmaceuticals, Inc. (Nasdaq: IDIX) announced today that SEBIVO(R) (telbivudine) has received approval from the Chinese State Food and Drug Administration (SFDA) as a once-a-day treatment, taken orally with or without food, for the treatment of chronic hepatitis B (CHB).  CHB remains a significant global health care concern, particularly in China where it affects more than 100 million people(1-3) - representing about one-third of those infected worldwide.(2) SEBIVO is expected to be available in China in April.     "The Chinese approval of telbivudine is positive news for the many CHB patients in China," said Dr. Calvin Q. Pan, MD, Director, Clinical Research/Hepatology, Mount Sinai Services at Elmhurst Hospital in New York City.  "As a physician who treats many CHB patients in the U.S., it is good to know that the patients in China will also have access to this new treatment option. Now, Chinese patients may also benefit from telbivudine's ability to provide early viral suppression, a primary goal of treatment."     Telbivudine received regulatory approval in the United States from the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in October 2006 for the treatment of CHB in adult patients with evidence of viral replication and active liver disease. Telbivudine is called TYZEKA in the United States and is called SEBIVO in all other countries. The approval of SEBIVO in China follows earlier approvals in Canada, Australia, Switzerland and several countries in Asia and Latin America. SEBIVO also recently received a positive opinion from the European Medicines Agency's (EMEA) Committee for Medicinal Products for Human Use (CHMP) recommending approval by the European Commission.     Worldwide regulatory submissions have been based primarily on one-year data from the GLOBE study, the largest worldwide registration trial including hepatitis B e-antigen (HBeAg)-positive and HBeAg-negative patients with CHB, and the first to include patients from China. The study results demonstrated that telbivudine provided potent viral suppression and high rates of PCR- negativity after one year.  An additional Chinese phase III trial, involving 332 adult Chinese patients with CHB, corroborated these findings and supplemented the filing in China.        About the GLOBE Study     Data from the worldwide phase III clinical trial, known as the GLOBE study, compared telbivudine to lamivudine, a commonly used antiviral therapy  for the treatment of CHB, in 1,367 patients.   In the GLOBE study, 60 and 40 percent of HBeAg-positive patients and 88 and 71 percent of HBeAg-negative patients achieved undetectable levels of HBV DNA (PCR-negativity) with telbivudine and lamivudine, respectively, at 52 weeks.  Additionally, patients who achieved undetectable HBV DNA levels at 24 weeks were more likely to undergo e-antigen seroconversion, PCR-negativity, normalize ALT, and minimize resistance at one year.     The primary efficacy endpoint of the GLOBE study was therapeutic response at one year, a composite endpoint coupling viral suppression (serum HBV DNA suppression below 100,000 copies/mL) with either improved liver disease markers (ALT normalization) or loss of detectable HBeAg. In HBeAg-positive patients, therapeutic response was 75% (n=345/458) among patients treated with telbivudine and 67% (n=310/463) for those patients treated with lamivudine, while the response for HBeAg-negative patients was 75% (n=167/222) vs. 77% (n=173/224), respectively.     In the GLOBE study, telbivudine was generally well tolerated with most adverse experiences classified as mild or moderate in severity. Frequently occurring adverse events (> 5%) for telbivudine v. lamivudine, respectively, were upper respiratory tract infection (14% v. 13%), fatigue and malaise (12% v. 11%), abdominal pain (12% v. 13%), nasopharyngitis (11% v. 10%), headache (11% v. 14%), blood CPK increased (9% v. 7%), cough (7% v. 6%),  nausea and vomiting (7% v. 6%), influenza and influenza-like symptoms (7% v. 8%), post- procedural pain (7% v. 6%), diarrhea and loose stools (7% v. 5%) and pharyngolaryngeal pain (5% v. 4%). Please see Important Safety Information.        Idenix/Novartis collaboration     Idenix and Novartis Pharma AG are co-promoting TYZEKA/SEBIVO, for the treatment of chronic hepatitis B, and co-developing valtorcitabine, a second hepatitis B compound, and valopicitabine, a hepatitis C compound, under a development and commercialization arrangement established in May 2003.  Under this agreement, Novartis and Idenix will co-promote TYZEKA/SEBIVO and, if approved, valtorcitabine and valopicitabine in the United States, France, Germany, Italy, Spain and the UK. Novartis has the exclusive right to commercialize TYZEKA/SEBIVO, valtorcitabine and valopicitabine in the rest of the world.        Important Information about Telbivudine     The following information about telbivudine is adapted from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration's approved product label.  It is anticipated that similar language related to the product's indication and important safety information will pertain to the product in global labeling.     Telbivudine is indicated for the treatment of chronic hepatitis B in adult patients with evidence of viral replication and either evidence of persistent elevations in serum aminotransferases (ALT or AST) or histologically active disease.  This indication is based on virologic, serologic, biochemical and histologic responses after one year of treatment in nucleoside-treatment-naïve adult patients with HBeAg-positive and HBeAg-negative chronic hepatitis B with compensated liver disease. Full prescribing information is available at www.tyzeka.com.          Important Safety Information about Telbivudine      -- Lactic acidosis and severe hepatomegaly with steatosis, including fatal         cases, have been reported with the use of nucleoside analogues alone or         in combination with antiretrovirals.      -- Severe acute exacerbations of hepatitis B have been reported in         patients who have discontinued anti-hepatitis B therapy, including         telbivudine. Hepatic function should be monitored closely with both         clinical and laboratory follow-up for at least several months in         patients who discontinue anti-hepatitis B therapy. If appropriate,         resumption of anti-hepatitis B therapy may be warranted.      -- Cases of myopathy have been reported with telbivudine use several weeks         to months after starting therapy. Myopathy has also been reported with         some other drugs in this class. Physicians considering concomitant         treatment with these or other agents associated with myopathy should         weigh carefully the potential benefits and risks and should monitor and         advise patients to report any signs or symptoms of unexplained muscle         pain, tenderness or weakness, particularly during periods of upward         dosage titration. Telbivudine therapy should be interrupted if myopathy         is suspected, and discontinued if myopathy is diagnosed.      -- Because telbivudine is eliminated primarily by renal excretion, co-         administration of telbivudine with drugs that affect renal function may         alter plasma concentrations of telbivudine and/or the co-administered         drug. Dose interval adjustment is recommended in patients with         creatinine clearance < 50mL/min including those with ESRD on         hemodialysis.  For patients on hemodialyis, telbivudine should be         administered after hemodialysis.      -- The safety and efficacy of telbivudine in liver transplant recipients         are unknown. If telbivudine treatment is determined to be necessary for         a liver transplant recipient who has received or is receiving an         immunosuppressant that may affect renal function, such as cyclosporine         or tacrolimus, renal function should be monitored both before and         during treatment with telbivudine.      -- Patients should be advised that treatment with telbivudine has not been         shown to reduce the risk of transmission of HBV to others through         sexual contact or blood contamination.      -- Safety and effectiveness of telbivudine in pediatric patients under the         age of 16 years have not been established.      -- Creatine kinase (CK) elevations were more frequent among subjects on         telbivudine treatment.  Grade 3/4 CK elevations occurred in 9% of         telbivudine-treated patients and 3% of lamivudine-treated patients.      -- The optimal duration of treatment with telbivudine has not been         established.  The relationship of initial treatment response to         outcomes such as hepatocellular carcinoma and decompensated cirrhosis         are unknown.        About Idenix     Idenix Pharmaceuticals, Inc., headquartered in Cambridge, MA, is a biopharmaceutical company engaged in the discovery and development of drugs for the treatment of human viral and other infectious diseases. Idenix's current focus is on the treatment of infections caused by hepatitis B virus, hepatitis C virus and human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).  For further information about Idenix, please refer to http://www.idenix.com.        Forward-looking statements     (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  March 02, 2007 07:00 ET (12:00 GMT)

Headline: : Royal Bank Of Canada Announces Increase To Common Share Dividend>RY.T
Story: TORONTO, March 2 /CNW/ - Royal Bank of Canada (RY on TSX and NYSE) today announced an increase to its quarterly common share dividend of six cents per share or 15 per cent to 46 cents, payable on May 24, 2007, to common shareholders of record on April 25, 2007.    The quarterly common share dividend was last increased by four cents per share to 40 cents in the fourth quarter of 2006, for shareholders of record on October 26, 2006.    The board also declared dividends on the following Non-Cumulative First Preferred Shares, payable on May 24, 2007, to shareholders of record on April 25, 2007.          <<      - Series N,  Dividend  No. 36  of  $0.29375 per share.      - Series W,  Dividend  No.  9  of  $0.30625 per share.      - Series AA, Dividend  No.  5  of  $0.278125 per share.      - Series AB, Dividend  No.  3  of  $0.293750 per share.      - Series AC, Dividend  No.  2  of  $0.2875 per share.      - Series AD, Dividend  No.  1  of  $0.499315 per share.      - Series AE, Dividend  No.  1  of  $0.385274 per share.      >>      The board also declared that all dividends (and deemed dividends) paid by the bank to Canadian residents on its common and preferred shares after December 31, 2005, are designated as "eligible dividends" for purposes of the enhanced dividend tax credit rules contained in the Income Tax Act (Canada) and any corresponding provincial and territorial tax legislation. In addition, the board declared that, unless stated otherwise, all dividends (and deemed dividends) paid by the bank hereafter are designated as "eligible dividends" for the purposes of such rules.             /CONTACT: Media Contact: Beja Rodeck, Media Relations, (416) 974-5506, toll-free 1-888-880-2173, beja.rodeck@rbc.com; Investor Contacts: Shirley Boudreau, Shareholder Relations, (416) 955-7806, shirley.boudreau@rbc.com; Dave Mun, Investor Relations, (416) 955-7808, dave.mun@rbc.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 02, 2007 07:40 ET (12:40 GMT)

Headline: WSJ(3/2) Nabors's Review Confirms Misdated Options Grants
Story: (From The Wall Street Journal)       By MARK MAREMONT and CHARLES FORELLE   NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--Nabors Industries Ltd. (NBR) said an internal review found it had misdated past stock-option grants, including some awarded on two dates when the recipients included its chief executive, Eugene Isenberg, one of the most highly compensated executives in history.   The contract oil-drilling company said options were wrongly dated as far back as 1991, and that it recorded a pretax charge of $51.6 million, or 13 cents per diluted share, in the 2006 fourth quarter, to account for understating past compensation expense for the wrongly dated options. The company said the review "made no finding of fraud or intentional wrongdoing."   Nabors, officially registered in Bermuda but managed from headquarters in Houston, becomes the latest company to acknowledge options-related troubles amid a broad federal inquiry into whether companies improperly enriched their executives by retroactively granting stock options at low points.   Yesterday's disclosures marked an about-face for Nabors, which late last year said it had examined its options-granting practices and found no problems. A pattern of fortunately timed grants to Mr. Isenberg was a focus of a page one article in The Wall Street Journal in December, which noted that, of 11 new option grants to Mr. Isenberg between 1991 and 2002, two were dated at quarterly lows for Nabors's stock price and five more at monthly lows.   The Securities and Exchange Commission began an informal probe of Nabors's options-granting practices following the article's publication.   In yesterday's regulatory filing, Nabors said the internal review identified certain option awards in which the company had used an "incorrect 'measurement date.' " The company said it misdated awards to top executives on four occasions between 1991 and 1997.   On Dec. 4, 1995, a monthly low in Nabors's stock, Mr. Isenberg received two million options, adjusted for a later stock split. Two others also received options with that date. Nabors says some options granted then should have been recorded as awarded on Jan. 8, 1996, and others on Jan. 18, 1996. Nabors's stock was between 9% and 15% higher on those dates.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 02, 2007 00:00 ET (05:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : SXC Health Solutions Announces Multi-Year Contract Renewal With MemberHealth
Story: - SXC to provide suite of PBM claims processing solutions to support Medicare Part D -       LOMBARD, IL, March 2 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ - SXC Health Solutions, Inc. ("SXC" or the "Company") (NASDAQ: SXCI, TSX: SXC), a leading provider of pharmacy benefits management ("PBM") services and healthcare IT solutions, announced today that it has renewed a multi-year contract with MemberHealth, Inc. an innovative PBM and major Medicare Part D provider based in Solon, Ohio.     Under terms of the contract, SXC will continue to provide MemberHealth with its suite of PBM services from its data center in Lisle, IL.     "We are delighted to extend our relationship with MemberHealth. They are a recognized market leader of Medicare Part D prescription drug benefits, with a strong focus on service and responsiveness to their members and pharmacy network. SXC is committed to work diligently with MemberHealth to support the various requirements of this high profile CMS program," said Gordon Glenn, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of SXC.     "SXC's suite of PBM processing services has been a key factor in our ability to handle the explosive growth we have seen in our Medicare product offering," stated Charles Hallberg, founder and CEO of MemberHealth. "SXC has been a strong and reliable technology partner for us."        About MemberHealth, Inc. (www.mhrx.com)     MemberHealth, Inc. (MHRx) is a leading national Medicare Part D sponsor, offering Medicare prescription drug plans in 50 states, District of Columbia, Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands. MHRx has more than 61,000 pharmacies in its pharmacy network and covers 98 percent of the top 100 medications taken by Medicare beneficiaries.     MHRx established its reputation as a visionary provider of prescription drug benefits for insured and self-insured groups and discount prescription programs across the country, by focusing on strengthening the relationships between patients, their pharmacists and physicians, which ensures that patients can take medicines with confidence and save money.     In 2006, MHRx was ranked #10 on the Inc. 500 list of fastest-growing, privately held companies in the country. MHRx received the Weatherhead 100 Centurion Award in 2006, honoring the fastest-growing Northeast Ohio companies with net sales of more than $100 million in 2005. For more information please visit www.mhrx.com or www.communitycarerx.com.        About SXC Health Solutions     SXC Health Solutions (SXC) is a leading provider of pharmacy benefits management (PBM) services and healthcare IT solutions to the healthcare benefits management industry. The Company's product offerings and solutions combine a wide range of software applications, application service provider (ASP) processing services and professional services, designed for many of the largest organizations in the pharmaceutical supply chain, such as Federal, provincial, and, state and local governments, pharmacy benefit managers, managed care organizations, retail pharmacy chains and other healthcare intermediaries. SXC is based in Lombard, Illinois with locations in; Scottsdale, Arizona; Warminster, Pennsylvania; Milton, Ontario and Victoria, British Columbia. For more information please visit www.sxc.com.        Forward-Looking Statements     Certain statements included herein, including those that express management's expectations or estimates of our future performance, constitute "forward-looking statements" within the meaning of applicable securities laws. Forward-looking statements are necessarily based upon a number of estimates and assumptions that, while considered reasonable by management at this time, are inherently subject to significant business, economic and competitive uncertainties and contingencies. Headline: Heineken US Selects Berlin Cameron As Advertising Agency
Story: Edited Press Release   AMSTERDAM (Dow Jones)--Dutch brewer Heineken NV (HINKY) said Friday that its unit Heineken USA selected Berlin Cameron United as its English-language advertising agency of record for the Heineken franchise, supporting both Heineken Lager and Heineken Premium Light in the United States.   The assignment will be effective immediately and represents a consolidation of English-language advertising for both Heineken Lager and Heineken Premium Light. Prior to the review, Heineken USA worked with Publicis USA on the Heineken Lager assignment, while Berlin Cameron handled advertising for the launch of Heineken Premium Light. MediaVest USA will continue to handle English-language media planning and buying for the Heineken USA brands and this work was not part of the review process.   Berlin Cameron will be charged with helping to build continued momentum for Heineken Premium Light as it enters its second year of national distribution, while helping the entire Heineken brand portfolio capture an ever-growing share of the premium import segment of the US beer market.   Company Web site: http://www.heinekeninternational.com         (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 02, 2007 03:34 ET (08:34 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Invitel Issues Consent Solicitation To Bondholders
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Hungarian telecommunications company Invitel has sent a consent solicitation to its bondholders seeking the waiver of a change-of-control clause on its bonds, a syndicate official at dealer manager Merrill Lynch said Friday.   Invitel's exiting cash-pay bonds include a change-of-control clause that allows bondholders to sell them back to the company at 101% of face value. The option would be triggered by the acquisiton of the company by Hungarian Telephone & Cable Corp. The amendment would allow the existing bonds to stay in place.   HTCC, whose controlling shareholder is Danish telecommunications company TDC, announced in early January, the acquisition of Invitel, the second-largest fixed-line telecommunications service provider in Hungary, for a total consideration of EUR470 million.   In addition, the bondholders have been asked to give approve amendments to Invitel's accounting that would allow Magyar Telecom BV, which issued the cash-pay notes, and Invitel Holdings NV, which issued payment-in-kind notes, to satisfy their reporting obligations through annual and quarterly filings of HTCC, the parent company, and annual statutory accounts at each issuer level.   The company also seeks to change their accounting rules to include the option of reporting under U.S. Generally Accepted Accounting Principles instead of International Financial Reporting Standards   Holders of the company's PIK notes are being asked to give their consent to amend the Consolidated Adjusted Net Income and Consolidated Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation and Amortization covenants to acknowledge the issuance of the new floating rate notes to finance the acquisition by HTCC.   The amendments are required to allow the company to execute the new bond deal, a person familar with the situation said. The new FRNs are expected to total around EUR200 million.   Investors are being offered a 12.5 basis-point consent fee. The consent solicitation process is scheduled to close March 9 and the consent of 50.1% of bondholders is needed to allow the amendments to go through, the person familar with the situation said.   -By Kate Haywood, Dow Jones Newswires, +44 (0) 7842 9315, kathryn.haywood@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 02, 2007 06:05 ET (11:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Galapagos announces 2006 full year results
Story: MECHELEN, BELGIUM -- (MARKET WIRE) -- 03/02/07 --      *  Revenues more than tripled to EUR 35.2 M  *  Year-end cash position of EUR 51.5 M  *  R&D spend increased from EUR 8.9 M in 2005 to EUR 15.9 M  *  Net loss per share increased from EUR 0.73 in 2005 to EUR 0.84  *  Established and progressed turn-key osteoarthritis alliance     with GlaxoSmithKline  *  Created biotech leader in bone and joint disease through     acquisition of ProSkelia  *  Built  top-tier service division with acquisitions of     Inpharmatica and DPI assets          Webcast audio conference presentation 9.30 CET at www.glpg.com        Mechelen, Belgium;  2 March  2007  - Galapagos  NV (Euronext  &  LSE: GLPG), an integrated drug discovery company, announces its full  year results for 2006 and provides market guidance for 2007.        In 2006,  Galapagos  succeeded  in  tripling  the  revenue  base  and accelerating the product pipeline towards the clinic.  An active  M&A strategy as  well as  organic growth  contributed to  these  results, creating a drug  discovery company well  balanced between  profitable services and  a  strong  product  pipeline.    Galapagos  made  major progress in  the  bone  and  joint programs  and  signed  a  turn-key alliance with GlaxoSmithKline in osteoarthritis.  The acquisition  of ProSkelia added a  number of  advanced bone disease  programs to  our portfolio as well as valuable expertise.  To fund the progression  of the combined  development  programs  towards and into  the  clinical testing  phase,  the  Company  raised  EUR 42  million  in two  private placements in 2006.  The  BioFocus DPI service division was  expanded through   two   acquisitions  (the   assets  of   Discovery   Partners International and Inpharmatica), to  become a world-leading  provider of drug discovery services.        Key figures 2006        (EUR   millions, except net loss per share)     Note: The drug discovery operations of Discovery Partners International Inc were acquired 6 July 2006. Inpharmatica Ltd was acquired on 6 December 2006, and ProSkelia SASU on 22 December 2006.      +-----------------------------------------------------------------+  |                           | Dec |---------------------------+--------------+----------------------|  | Other                     |          0,4 |                  0,2 |  |---------------------------+--------------+----------------------|  | Net loss for the period   |        -11,3 |                 -6,5 |  |---------------------------+--------------+----------------------|  | Basic loss per share (EUR)|        -0.84 |                -0.73 |  |---------------------------+--------------+----------------------|  |                           |              |                      |  |---------------------------+--------------+----------------------|  | Cash and cash equivalents |         51,5 |                 23,6 |  +-----------------------------------------------------------------+          "In 2006,  we  saw  the  BioFocus  DPI  service  division  deliver  aprofitable segment  result and  strong  organic revenue  growth,  far  outpacing market growth rates.   The acquisitions  made in 2006  will solidify  the division's  top tier  position and  the combined  entity should secure  continued growth,"  stated Onno van  de Stolpe, CEO  of Galapagos.  "In our  internal  drug discovery, we made great  progress in all  of  our therapeutic  programs.    The alliance  with  GSK  in osteoarthritis has  enabled  us  to   gear up  this  program  for  the delivery of clinical candidates.  By  acquiring ProSkelia, we obtained a number  of bone  programs based  on clinically  validated  targets, derisking our portfolio and increasing the chances of having  multipleprograms in  the clinic  in 2008.     This year  we intend  to  fully  capitalize on the combined synergies of the acquisitions completed in 2006,  placing us in prime position to become one of Europe's  leading biotechs."        "The  major  steps  taken  in  2006  have  transformed  the   Company financially   for   2007,"  said   David  Smith,   Galapagos'  CFO. "Accordingly, we anticipate that  Group revenues in  2007 will be  in the range of EUR 54-58 million.  Furthermore, with a significant step up in  R&D  investment  to support  progression  of  our  clinical  and pre-clinical programs in  2007, we  expect that full  year cash  burn will be EUR 20 million."        Operational overview        Drug discovery division        In our rheumatoid arthritis (RA)  program, lead compounds have  shown good pharmacokinetic  properties  and  efficacy  in  relevant  animal models of  the  disease.    These  molecules  also  show  substantial protection against  bone  loss in  the  industry standard  RA  animal models.  The compounds target  a proprietary kinase protein that  was identified  using  the  Galapagos'  SilenceSelect  target   discovery platform.  Based on these encouraging results, Galapagos  anticipates initiation of pre-clinical studies in  2007, with the potential of  a candidate drug entering clinical Phase I in 2008.        On 7 June 2006, Galapagos and GlaxoSmithKline's Center of  Excellence for External Drug Discovery announced  a turn-key drug discovery  and development alliance  in osteoarthritis  (OA) worth  EUR 137 million  in upfront, milestone,  and  equity  payments  and  up  to  double-digit royalties on  commercial products. Galapagos  will build  upon  its existing OA program to deliver drug candidates from target through to clinical Phase IIa  proof of  concept. This  alliance validated  the Company's target discovery  platform as  well as  our drug  discovery capabilities.  In this program, Galapagos reported the achievement of Proof of Principle  with compounds against  its proprietary  targets,showing ex vivo protection of  bovine cartilage explants.   Galapagos has several series of compounds in hit-to-lead and lead  optimization that have potential to deliver  novel therapeutics for the  treatment of OA.     With the  acquisition of  ProSkelia on  22 December  2006,  Galapagos enhanced its product portfolio with the addition of three programs in bone diseases (two for osteoporosis and one for bone metastasis), and one in cachexia (muscle atrophy and weight loss).  The combined  drug discovery portfolio  will contribute  to  Galapagos' goal  of  having multiple clinical programs in bone and  joint diseases by the end  of 2008.   The transaction  with ProSkelia also included  an  exclusive license option to oestradiol glucoside (E2G), a product for treatment of 'hot flashes', a  menopausal symptom.   Galapagos has started  the preparations to initiate a Phase IIb clinical trial for this compoundin Q4  of 2007.   In  addition to  its programs,  the acquisition  of ProSkelia contributes capabilities and  facilities that will  greatly accelerate the Galapagos programs in bone and joint diseases.        BioFocus DPI division        Galapagos acquired  Inpharmatica and  the operational  activities  of Discovery Partners  International as  part of  its strategy  to  make BioFocus  DPI  a worldwide  leader in  drug discovery  services.   The appeal of  this synergistic  offering has  been validated  through  a number of  recent deals in  which  a combination  of  services  were included,  like  the  recently   announced  collaboration  with   the University  of  Bristol  that  combines  Inpharmatica's  Admensa  and BioFocus DPI's medicinal chemistry expertise.        BioFocus DPI  continues  to  be  successful  in  securing  multi-year contracts such  as  the  three-year target  discovery  alliance  with Arthrogen, the three-year exclusive  library contract with Roche  and the extension of its long term collaboration with Amgen into 2008.        BioFocus DPI  also expanded  its solid  relationship with  non-profit organizations by initiating a multi-year drug discovery collaboration with OneWorld Health,  entering a new  EUR 2.4 million target  discovery alliance with the  ALS Association, and extending the  collaboration with the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation.        In addition to  these previously announced  service deals,  Galapagos also announces  today  that  BioFocus  DPI  has  extended  its  drug discovery agreement with Eli Lilly  and Company (NYSE: LLY) until  the end of 2007. Total contract extension value is expected to exceed EUR 1 million.        Details of the financial results        Revenue     Galapagos' revenues for the full year 2006 more than tripled to EUR 35.2 million (2005: EUR 11.2 million). Of these revenues, EUR 31.0 million were generated by BioFocus DPI.  The Drug Discovery division contributed EUR 4.2 million to Group revenues.        Results        BioFocus DPI contributed approximately EUR 3.4 million to the result  of the Group on a  segment basis in  2006.  The Group  net loss for  the     (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  March 02, 2007 02:17 ET (07:17 GMT)

Headline: British Broadcasting Corp Signs Partnership With YouTube -4-
Story: The deal with YouTube comes as the BBC Trust, the corporation's new governance body, considers whether to allow the corporation to advertise on its international Web sites.   The corporation is funded through a universal license fee in the U.K. and advertising isn't permitted on any of its U.K. broadcast platforms or its domestic Web site.   The BBC's director general, Mark Thompson, in a statement said YouTube was "a key gateway through which to engage new audiences in the U.K. and abroad."   Chad Hurley, CEO of YouTube, said he hoped YouTube, through the deal, could "open up an entirely new audience for (BBC) content."   Company Web site: http://www.bbc.co.uk, http://www.youtube.com, http://www.google.com   -By Jessica Hodgson, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 207 842 92 93; jessica.hodgson@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 02, 2007 07:11 ET (12:11 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE: NIBC To Seek Listing On Euronext; FY Net Pft +82%
Story: (This updates an item that ran at 0722 GMT with additional detail.)       By Nicolas Parasie     Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     AMSTERDAM (Dow Jones)--Merchant bank NIBC on Friday said it will seek an initial public offering on Euronext Amsterdam in the coming months, as it reported a sharp rise in full-year net profit.   "A listing will provide NIBC with strategic and financial flexibility to fund growth, both organically and through potential acquisitions, via permanent access to the capital markets," NIBC said.   The joint bookrunners will be ABN AMRO Rothschild (ABN), Goldman Sachs (GS), Credit Suisse (CS) and JPMorgan (JPM). Fox-Pitt, Kelton and NIBC Bank N.V. will act as co-lead managers, the company said.   The Hague-based company also reported an 82% rise in net profit for 2006 to EUR288 million from EUR158 million in the previous year.   "We believe that the 2006 results provide a solid base and good starting point to realize our long-held ambition to list on Euronext Amsterdam," Chief Executive Michael Enthoven said in a statement.   NIBC was acquired in 2005 by an international investor group led by New York-based investment fund J.C. Flowers & Co., for EUR2.1 billion. J.C. Flowers will retain a 20% stake after the IPO, Enthoven said.   Enthoven didn't provide further details of the offering. "All I can say is it will be less than 49.9%" of the company that will be floated, he said.   Company Web site: http://www.nibc.com     - By Nicolas Parasie, Dow Jones Newswires; nicolas.parasie@dowjones.com; 31 20 6260770     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 02, 2007 05:18 ET (10:18 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Webcast Alert: Isis Pharmaceuticals' Financial Results and Highlights for 2006 Conference Call
Story: Webcast Alert: Isis Pharmaceuticals' Financial Results and  Highlights for 2006 Conference Call       CARLSBAD, Calif., March 2, 2007 (PRIME NEWSWIRE) -- Isis  Pharmaceuticals, Inc. (Nasdaq:ISIS) announces the following webcast:      What:       Financial Results and Highlights for 2006       When:       Thursday, March 8, 2007, at 11:00 a.m. ET / 8:00 a.m. PT       Where:      www.isispharm.com       How:        Live on the Internet.  Simply log onto our website listed                above.          If you are unable to participate during the live event, a  replay of the webcast will be available for a limited time at  www.isispharm.com.       About Isis Pharmaceuticals, Inc.       Isis is exploiting its expertise in RNA to discover and  develop novel drugs for its product pipeline and for its partners. The  Company has successfully commercialized the world's first antisense  drug and has 15 drugs in development. Isis' drug development programs  are aimed at treating cardiovascular, metabolic and inflammatory  diseases. Isis' partners are focused in disease areas such as ocular,  viral and neurodegenerative diseases, and cancer. Ibis Biosciences,  Inc., Isis' wholly owned subsidiary, is developing and commercializing  the Ibis T5000 Biosensor System, a revolutionary system to identify  infectious organisms. As an innovator in RNA-based drug discovery and  development, Isis is the owner or exclusive licensee of approximately  1,500 issued patents worldwide. Additional information about Isis is  available at www.isispharm.com.       CONTACT:  Isis Pharmaceuticals, Inc.             Kate Corcoran, Ph.D.             Vice President, Corporate Development             (760) 603-2331       (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 02, 2007 07:01 ET (12:01 GMT)

Headline: THE SKEPTIC: Risk Of Spain's Real-Estate Roof Caving In
Story: By Martin Fluck     A DOW JONES NEWSWIRES COLUMN     LONDON (Dow Jones)--The decision by Spanish property group Metrovacesa to divide itself into two may have inadvertently exposed the Spanish real-estate and construction sector to the harsh light of day.   It was hardly surprising that shares in the company collapsed last month when, as part of the restructuring plan to end a feud between Metrovacesa's shareholders, the company valued itself at EUR75.67 a share, some 36% below the share price at the time.   The fight for control of Metrovacesa artificially inflated the stock price, but the old valuation wasn't out of line with some other companies in the sector.   Indeed, some investors have long argued the valuations of Spanish property and construction companies are stretched, failing to reflect the risk tighter European monetary policy could lead to a credit crunch and property-market correction in Spain in 2007.   Now, the roughly 10% knocked off the share prices of other Spanish companies like Sacyr Vallehermoso, Acciona, and Ferrovial this week was part of the markets selloff.   But the Spanish companies are vulnerable to a reassessment of financial-market risk because of the debt on their balance sheets. Balances of non-financial companies in Spain are 10% in deficit, compared with a surplus of 2% in Germany and the U.K.   Metrovacesa finds itself in the same boat. At the end of 2006, its book-gearing was 153%. While its Ebit, before asset revaluation, covered interest 2.7X, this could deteriorate rapidly should profitability slip. After all, interest expenses rose 37% in 2006 to EUR359 million.   The fortunes of Spain's real-estate and construction companies are arguably central to the outlook for the Spanish economy in 2007 given the fears the construction boom that has underpinned the country's growth is at an end.   The Bank of Spain has warned about the dangerous levels of debt taken on by developers and construction companies, and thinks Spanish property may be 40% overvalued.   Rising ECB rates have pushed up the cost of that debt for companies but are yet to have their full impact on Spanish households. They aren't as indebted as in Ireland or the U.K., but because almost all Spanish mortgages are variable, adjusted only every 6 months, there's a lagged effect of last year's ECB rate rises which might crimp discretionary spending through 2007.   As it is, falling residential rents, slowing house price growth, amid an overhang of new housing, look ominous for the Spanish economy. Analysts at Merrill Lynch are among those worried overbuilding might hit asset values hard and feed through to the banks, a large proportion of whose loans are to the construction industry.   With the interest expenses of non-financial Spanish companies rising, the "normalization" of credit conditions might squeeze Spanish construction and real estate companies particularly hard, quite apart from the wider economy.   That's why the near tripling of Metrovacesa's net profit in 2006, which included an upward revaluation of property assets, may prove to be a trailing indicator.     (Martin Fluck joined Dow Jones Newswires in 2006. He has previously worked as a commodities trader, currency and equity analyst, and financial reporter. He can be reached at +44 207 842 9287 or by e-mail: martin.fluck@dowjones.com)     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 02, 2007 06:20 ET (11:20 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Immtech CEO Asks For Option Grant To Be Cut From Job Pact>IMM
Story: DOW JONES NEWSWIRES   Immtech Pharmaceuticals Inc. (IMM) said Friday it amended and restated Chief Executive Eric. L. Sorkin's employment agreement to remove the requirement that he be granted an option to purchase 325,000 shares of the company's stock.   According to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Sorkin requested the board amend his agreement to remove the requirement and to provide that he will be eligible for future stock options conditioned on Immtech's achievements and milestones as determined by the company.   Shares of the New York pharmaceutical company closed Thursday at $5.78.     -Ingrid Pedrick Lehrfeld, Dow Jones Newswires; 202-862-1361     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 02, 2007 07:19 ET (12:19 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Indonesia Awards 9 Oil Blocks;Initial Investment $411.1M -2-
Story: Esso Exploration International, a unit of Exxon Mobil Corp. (XOM), was awarded with the Mandar block offshore West Sulawesi.   The other companies awarded were mostly local, little-known companies.   The nine blocks are part of 20 blocks that Indonesia had offered to investors. It failed to attract interest in all of them.   Director General of Oil and Gas  and the ministry Luluk Sumiarso said the government will re-offer the 11 blocks in April.   Sumiarso added that the government hopes to offer around 40 blocks in total this year.   The only Southeast Asian member of the Organization Petroleum Exporting Countries has seen its crude oil production dwindle to 30-year lows last year with most of its wells maturing.     -By Deden Sudrajat, contributing to Dow Jones Newswires; 62-21 39831277; I-Made.Sentana@dowjones.com   -Edited by Ryan Woo     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 02, 2007 03:41 ET (08:41 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Wendy's To Bypass NYC Order To Post Calories - NYT
Story: NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--Wendy's International (WEN) pulled nutrition posters with calorie information from its New York City locations in an effort to free itself from a city regulation requiring some restaurants to provide calorie data on menus and menu boards, The New York Times reported in its Friday editions.   The Board of Health rule does not go into effect until July, but the rule applies solely to restaurants that voluntarily provided calorie information in some form to its customers, whether online, on posters or in brochures, "on or after March 1." The regulation is the only one of its kind in the nation.   The paper added that the restaurant industry has been adamantly opposed to the regulation, saying it unfairly penalizes a majority of big fast food and chain restaurants that already provide nutritional information to its customers, while leaving untouched restaurants that give no such information. They also say that abiding by the new regulation will be costly.   Wendy's posted a disclaimer stating that it could not provide calorie information to its New York City customers because of the regulation.   "We fully support the intent of this regulation," the disclaimer states, "however, since most of our food is made to order, there isn't enough room on our existing menu boards to comply with the regulation."   The Times reported that although Wendy's was the only major restaurant chain to publicly announce its actions, the Board of Health said in a statement that it appeared some other food outlets were following suit.   New York City health officials would not say which restaurants appeared to have pulled calorie information, but a review of some fast food company Web sites found about six whose nutrition information sections were down last night. The New York Times is not naming them because representatives of those companies could not be reached.   Newsapaper Web Site: http://www.nytimes.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  March 02, 2007 02:20 ET (07:20 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
